title: China Development Bank provides $85 million buyer’s credit loan for Melnykov Coal Mine Modernization Project (Linked to Project ID#42513)
description: On September 2, 2010, China Development Bank and the Government of Ukraine’s Ministry of Energy and the Coal Industry signed a $1.03 billion loan framework agreement (captured via Project ID#42513). The agreement was signed by Yuriy Yaschenko, the Ukrainian Minister of Energy and the Coal Industry and Chen Yuan, the Chairman of CDB. It identified seven investment projects that the CDB would consider supporting via subsidiary loans under the framework agreement. Then, on December 21, 2011, China Development Bank and OJSC Lysychanskvuhillya (also known as ВАТ "Лисичанськвугілля" or товариство "Лисичанськвугілля”) — a state-owned Ukrainian coal company — signed an $85 million subsidiary buyer’s credit loan agreement [№15010-02/191].   The borrowing terms of the loan were as follows: a 9-year maturity, 3 year grace period, and an annual interest rate of 7.05%. The loan’s final maturity date is December 21, 2020. On December 26, 2011, the Government of Ukraine’s Ministry of Finance issued a sovereign guarantee in support of this loan. The borrower was expected to use the loan proceeds to finance a commercial contract (№ 06-214 / 2) that it signed with Tian Di Science & Technology Co., Ltd (Ukrainian: "Тіанди" Сайнес енд Технолоджи Ко., Лтд”) on March 7, 2012.   The CDB loan's amount outstanding was $46.24 million as December 31, 2017 and $20.4 million as of January 1, 2020.  The purpose of the project was to re-equip and modernize the Melnikov (Melnykov) Coal Mine (Ukrainian: Шахта ім. Мельникова) in the city of Lysychansk within Luhansk Region.   OJSC Lysychanskvuhillya received and tested the equipment that it acquired from Tian Di Science & Technology Co., Ltd on October 20, 2012.  The project was completed in September 2013.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Melnikov Coal Mine Modernization Project. The Ukrainian project title is проекту щодо технічного переоснащення та модернізації ВП «Шахти ім. Д.Ф. Мельникова». The Chinese project title is 乌克兰梅利尼科瓦煤矿现代化技术改造项目 or 款的乌克兰梅利尼科娃煤矿改造项目 or 梅利尼科娃煤矿改造项目. 2. This CDB loan is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset published by Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Development Bank provides $85 million buyer’s credit loan for Melnykov Coal Mine Modernization Project (Linked to Project ID#42513)

# Description
On September 2, 2010, China Development Bank and the Government of Ukraine’s Ministry of Energy and the Coal Industry signed a $1.03 billion loan framework agreement (captured via Project ID#42513). The agreement was signed by Yuriy Yaschenko, the Ukrainian Minister of Energy and the Coal Industry and Chen Yuan, the Chairman of CDB. It identified seven investment projects that the CDB would consider supporting via subsidiary loans under the framework agreement. Then, on December 21, 2011, China Development Bank and OJSC Lysychanskvuhillya (also known as ВАТ "Лисичанськвугілля" or товариство "Лисичанськвугілля”) — a state-owned Ukrainian coal company — signed an $85 million subsidiary buyer’s credit loan agreement [№15010-02/191].   The borrowing terms of the loan were as follows: a 9-year maturity, 3 year grace period, and an annual interest rate of 7.05%. The loan’s final maturity date is December 21, 2020. On December 26, 2011, the Government of Ukraine’s Ministry of Finance issued a sovereign guarantee in support of this loan. The borrower was expected to use the loan proceeds to finance a commercial contract (№ 06-214 / 2) that it signed with Tian Di Science & Technology Co., Ltd (Ukrainian: "Тіанди" Сайнес енд Технолоджи Ко., Лтд”) on March 7, 2012.   The CDB loan's amount outstanding was $46.24 million as December 31, 2017 and $20.4 million as of January 1, 2020.  The purpose of the project was to re-equip and modernize the Melnikov (Melnykov) Coal Mine (Ukrainian: Шахта ім. Мельникова) in the city of Lysychansk within Luhansk Region.   OJSC Lysychanskvuhillya received and tested the equipment that it acquired from Tian Di Science & Technology Co., Ltd on October 20, 2012.  The project was completed in September 2013.
justification: Project focuses on modernization of a coal mine, directly supporting coal production and fossil fuel dependency
evidence: Modernization of Melnykov Coal Mine, coal industry focus, equipment for coal mining operations

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 80 million grant for provision of 17,193 computers to secondary schools
description: On June 20, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ukraine signed letters of exchange, which committed RMB 80 million of grant funding for unspecified purposes. The grant proceeds were reportedly used to deliver 17,193 computers to secondary schools in Ukraine. However, precise project implementation start and end dates are unavailable.
staff_comments: The Ukrainian project title is комп’ютерне обладнання (17 193 комплекти). One official source suggests that this project was support by a grant agreement (letters of exchange) that was signed on February 24, 2012 rather than June 20, 2011. This issue merits further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 80 million grant for provision of 17,193 computers to secondary schools

# Description
On June 20, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ukraine signed letters of exchange, which committed RMB 80 million of grant funding for unspecified purposes. The grant proceeds were reportedly used to deliver 17,193 computers to secondary schools in Ukraine. However, precise project implementation start and end dates are unavailable.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of computers to secondary schools, education sector focus

title: China and Ukraine researchers cooperate for the creation of the Paton Welding Institute in Ukraine
description: On February 24, 2011, an agreement was signed in Kyiv, Ukraine stating that China Ministry of Science and Technology, Guangdong Provincial Government and the Ukraine are to build a welding institute for research and development, known as the "China - Ukraine Paton welding Institute" (Guangzhou, China).  On June 20, 2011, a memorandum of understanding was signed between the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology and the Ukrainian State Agency for Science, Innovation, and Information in order to start construction of the Paton Welding Institute. The institute is named after Boris Paton, Dean of the Ukrainian National Academy of Sciences and Director of the Paton Institute.  In 2017, the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology approved the project as a "National International Science and Technology Base".   On August 15, 2019, a delegation from Ukraine's Paton Institute of Electric Welding visited the completed China-Ukraine Barton Welding Research Institute, constructed over a period of eight years.   The China-Ukraine Paton Welding Research Institute (中国－乌克兰巴顿焊接研究院”的组建标)  is supported by the Ministry of Science and Technology of China and the Guangdong Provincial People's Government. The institute will carry out scientific and technological activities of modern welding and related technologies based on the innovative technology and promote them in Chinese industrial enterprises to spread the development of science and technology at Guangdong's industrial level. Both countries will support the Research Institute.   The China-Ukraine Paton Welding Research Institute  was established in China's Guangdong Institute of Welding Technology. In 2017, one of the China-Ukraine Paton Welding Research Institute's dean's reported that since its establishment, the institute has has undertaken more than 30 national, provincial, and municipal scientific research projects, carried out technical support and promotion services for more than 100 companies, published more than 300 papers, and obtained 56 patent authorizations. Additionally, the company engaged in horizontal cooperation with well-known domestic enterprises such as China Aerospace, AVIC, China Shipbuilding, Pangang Group, Dongfang Electric, and others.

# Sector

# Title
China and Ukraine researchers cooperate for the creation of the Paton Welding Institute in Ukraine

# Description
On February 24, 2011, an agreement was signed in Kyiv, Ukraine stating that China Ministry of Science and Technology, Guangdong Provincial Government and the Ukraine are to build a welding institute for research and development, known as the "China - Ukraine Paton welding Institute" (Guangzhou, China).  On June 20, 2011, a memorandum of understanding was signed between the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology and the Ukrainian State Agency for Science, Innovation, and Information in order to start construction of the Paton Welding Institute. The institute is named after Boris Paton, Dean of the Ukrainian National Academy of Sciences and Director of the Paton Institute.  In 2017, the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology approved the project as a "National International Science and Technology Base".   On August 15, 2019, a delegation from Ukraine's Paton Institute of Electric Welding visited the completed China-Ukraine Barton Welding Research Institute, constructed over a period of eight years.   The China-Ukraine Paton Welding Research Institute (中国－乌克兰巴顿焊接研究院”的组建标)  is supported by the Ministry of Science and Technology of China and the Guangdong Provincial People's Government. The institute will carry out scientific and technological activities of modern welding and related technologies based on the innovative technology and promote them in Chinese industrial enterprises to spread the development of science and technology at Guangdong's industrial level. Both countries will support the Research Institute.   The China-Ukraine Paton Welding Research Institute  was established in China's Guangdong Institute of Welding Technology. In 2017, one of the China-Ukraine Paton Welding Research Institute's dean's reported that since its establishment, the institute has has undertaken more than 30 national, provincial, and municipal scientific research projects, carried out technical support and promotion services for more than 100 companies, published more than 300 papers, and obtained 56 patent authorizations. Additionally, the company engaged in horizontal cooperation with well-known domestic enterprises such as China Aerospace, AVIC, China Shipbuilding, Pangang Group, Dongfang Electric, and others.
justification: Project focuses on research and education in welding technology, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Welding research institute, scientific and technological activities, education and research focus

title: Hanban funds the establishment of Confucius Institute at South Ukrainian National Pedagogical University
description: On September 28, 2011, the Confucius Institute at South Ukrainian National Pedagogical University (SUNPU or Південноукраїнський національний педагогічний університет імені К. Д. Ушинського) was founded in Odessa, Ukraine. The institute was founded through cooperation between the South Ukrainian National Pedagogical University and Harbin Engineering University.

title: Chinese Government sponsors construction of China-Ukraine Agricultural Cooperation Park
description: In April 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ukraine signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) regarding the construction of the China-Ukraine Agricultural Cooperation Park. In August 2011, the first meeting of the Agricultural Cooperation Subcommittee of the China-Ukraine Cooperation Committee was held in China. The nature and monetary value of the Chinese government financing for this project is unknown.   The purpose of the project was to support the purchase of pesticides, seeds, agricultural machinery and other necessary agricultural products from China to Ukraine; promote high-quality Ukrainian agricultural products to China), and facilitate the implementation of EPC contracts (for the construction of pesticide plants and organic fertilizer processing plants, among things), and support the implementation of investment projects in Ukraine (such as land cultivation and planting and other projects). Construction was carried out by Henan Huangfan District Industrial Group Co., Ltd, a Chinese company based in Henan Province. On April 26, 2016, the park opened.
staff_comments: The Ukrainian project title is китайського-українсько технологічного парку в агропромисловій сфері. The Chinese project title is 乌克兰中乌农业科技示范园区.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government sponsors construction of China-Ukraine Agricultural Cooperation Park

# Description
In April 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ukraine signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) regarding the construction of the China-Ukraine Agricultural Cooperation Park. In August 2011, the first meeting of the Agricultural Cooperation Subcommittee of the China-Ukraine Cooperation Committee was held in China. The nature and monetary value of the Chinese government financing for this project is unknown.   The purpose of the project was to support the purchase of pesticides, seeds, agricultural machinery and other necessary agricultural products from China to Ukraine; promote high-quality Ukrainian agricultural products to China), and facilitate the implementation of EPC contracts (for the construction of pesticide plants and organic fertilizer processing plants, among things), and support the implementation of investment projects in Ukraine (such as land cultivation and planting and other projects). Construction was carried out by Henan Huangfan District Industrial Group Co., Ltd, a Chinese company based in Henan Province. On April 26, 2016, the park opened.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural cooperation and infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Agricultural cooperation park, focus on agricultural products and machinery, construction of pesticide and fertilizer plants, land cultivation projects

title: Chinese Government provides grant — via ETCA — to provide computers to Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Linked to Project ID#42470)
description: On October 28, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ukraine signed letters of exchange, which committed grant funding for the provision of a batch of computers to the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The grant proceeds that supported this project were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on April 12, 2007 (see Project ID#42470). Huawei Technologies Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. The Ambassador of Ukraine to the People's Republic of China Yuriy Kostenko met with a regional representative of Huawei Technologies Ltd. in Beijing on August 13, 2012 to discuss the implementation of this computer equipment project. The project was evidently completed because in December 2020 the U.S. Under Secretary of State for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment Keith J. Krach announced that the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry had decided to get rid of all Huawei equipment installed in its buildings. However, precise project implementation start and end dates are unavailable.
staff_comments: The Ukrainian project title is надання комп'ютерного обладнання для Міністерства закордонних справ України
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant — via ETCA — to provide computers to Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Linked to Project ID#42470)

# Description
On October 28, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ukraine signed letters of exchange, which committed grant funding for the provision of a batch of computers to the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The grant proceeds that supported this project were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on April 12, 2007 (see Project ID#42470). Huawei Technologies Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. The Ambassador of Ukraine to the People's Republic of China Yuriy Kostenko met with a regional representative of Huawei Technologies Ltd. in Beijing on August 13, 2012 to discuss the implementation of this computer equipment project. The project was evidently completed because in December 2020 the U.S. Under Secretary of State for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment Keith J. Krach announced that the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry had decided to get rid of all Huawei equipment installed in its buildings. However, precise project implementation start and end dates are unavailable.
justification: Project involves provision of computer equipment to government ministry, with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Provision of computers to Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides $52.1 million for Tranche 1 of buyer’s credit loan for Aerial Express Project (Linked to Project ID#42494 and ID#42577)
description: On September 3, 2010, the Government of Ukraine’s State Investment Agency and the Export-Import Bank of China (China Eximbank) signed a loan framework agreement regarding the Aerial Express Project. Then, on July 5, 2011, China Eximbank and SC "National Project "Airexpress" (Ukrainian: «Дирекція з будівництва та управління національного проекту «Повітряний експрес») — a project company and special purpose vehicle (SPV) that was created by the Government of Ukraine — signed a $372,313,538 buyer’s credit loan agreement [№ BLA201123] for the Aerial Express Project. The borrowing terms of this loan were as follows: a 15 year maturity, a 3 year grace period, and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.414% in July 2011) plus a 3.5% margin. Ukraine’s Cabinet of Ministers issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan on June 16, 2011. SC "National Project "Airexpress" also purchased buyer’s credit insurance from Sinosure on July 25, 2012 (at an additional cost of $36.39 million).   The China Eximbank loan was split into two tranches. The first tranche was worth $52,123,895 and it was earmarked for design and preparatory work (phase 1 of the project). The second tranche was worth $320,189,643 and it was earmarked for construction activities (phase 2 of the project). The borrower was to use the proceeds of the loan to finance two separate EPC contracts with China National Complete Engineering Corporation (CMCEC) that were signed on April 18, 2011. One EPC contract was for Phase 1 and the other EPC contract was for Phase 2. The purpose of the Aerial Express Project was to construct an 4.752 km passenger railway from Boryspil International Airport (BIA) to the capital city of Kiev. It was also supposed to involve the installation of supporting electricity systems, information systems, signaling system, water supply and drainage systems, two new train stations, and one electricity substation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on December 28, 2011. However, construction did not begin until 6.5 years later.   The first tranche of the loan fully disbursed in July 2013 and shortly thereafter many questions arose about the use of these funds. Law enforcement officers uncovered large-scale fraud involving the purchase of land, and Ukraine’s Center for Transport Studies (CTS) reported on November 21, 2013 that employees of SC "National Project "Airexpress" stole $20 million from the first tranche of the China Eximbank loan and spent the remaining $32,123,895 without producing a final project design. Consequently, China Eximbank never disbursed the loan’s second tranche. The Government of Ukraine also had difficulty meeting its repayment obligations related to the loan’s first tranche. The Chinese Economic and Commercial Office in Ukraine initially reported that Ukraine’s Ministry of Finance had failed to honor its sovereign guarantee. Then, in July 2014, China Eximbank agreed to grant SC "National Project "Airexpress" an additional 2-year loan repayment holiday (i.e. grace period) on the first tranche of the loan. The Government of Ukraine — as the guarantor of the loan — eventually stepped in and fully repaid the ($52,123,895) first loan tranche. It also unsuccessfully attempted to reallocate the second loan tranche to the Podil-Voskresensk Bridge Project and the Kiev Subway Extension Project.   Additionally, the Government of Ukraine initiated talks with Sinosure regarding the possibility of recovering approximately $30 million via insurance payments, but the outcome of these negotiations is unknown. Project ID#67775 captures the first tranche of the loan and Project ID#42577 captures the July 2014 rescheduling of the first tranche of the loan. Project ID#42494 captures the de facto cancellation of the second tranche of the loan. On June 17, 2015, responsibility for the Aerial Express Project was transferred from SC "National Project "Airexpress" to the Ukrainian Ministry of Infrastructure. The State Administration of Railway Transport of Ukraine (Ukrzaliznytsia) subsequently assumed responsibility for the EPC contract from CMCEC and it was charged with financing a scaled-down and rescoped version of the project. Construction began on May 22, 2018 and Ukrzaliznytsia announced on November 30, 2018 that the first trains had left from Kiev to Boryspil airport. Vladyslav Kaskiv, the former Head of Ukraine’s State Agency for Investment and National Projects, was closely involved in the Aerial Express Project. He put on an International wanted list in March 2016. He was detained in Panama in September 2016. A local court set his bail at $600,000. The Government of Panama refused to grant Kaskiv a political refugee status, and has was later extradited to Ukraine. Subsequently, Kaskiv was released on bail. As of May 2020, his case was pending before the High Anti-Corruption Court of Ukraine. Ukrzaliznytsia, a nationally owned company of Ukraine, took over the implementation and finished construction in a smaller scale. On November 30, 2018, Ukrzaliznytsia launched an express train to Boryspil airport with a floating schedule of 21-30 voyages per day.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Ukrainian Air Express Airport Railway Project and the Rail Transit linking Borispol International Airport Project and the Kyiv Boryspil Express Project. The Ukrainian project title is 'Дирекція з будівництва та управління національного проекту 'Повітряний експрес' та інших інфраструктурних об'єктів Київського регіону”. The Chinese project title is 空中快车 or 《空中快车》项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides $52.1 million for Tranche 1 of buyer’s credit loan for Aerial Express Project (Linked to Project ID#42494 and ID#42577)

# Description
On September 3, 2010, the Government of Ukraine’s State Investment Agency and the Export-Import Bank of China (China Eximbank) signed a loan framework agreement regarding the Aerial Express Project. Then, on July 5, 2011, China Eximbank and SC "National Project "Airexpress" (Ukrainian: «Дирекція з будівництва та управління національного проекту «Повітряний експрес») — a project company and special purpose vehicle (SPV) that was created by the Government of Ukraine — signed a $372,313,538 buyer’s credit loan agreement [№ BLA201123] for the Aerial Express Project. The borrowing terms of this loan were as follows: a 15 year maturity, a 3 year grace period, and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.414% in July 2011) plus a 3.5% margin. It also unsuccessfully attempted to reallocate the second loan tranche to the Podil-Voskresensk Bridge Project and the Kiev Subway Extension Project.   Additionally, the Government of Ukraine initiated talks with Sinosure regarding the possibility of recovering approximately $30 million via insurance payments, but the outcome of these negotiations is unknown. Project ID#67775 captures the first tranche of the loan and Project ID#42577 captures the July 2014 rescheduling of the first tranche of the loan. Project ID#42494 captures the de facto cancellation of the second tranche of the loan. On June 17, 2015, responsibility for the Aerial Express Project was transferred from SC "National Project "Airexpress" to the Ukrainian Ministry of Infrastructure. The State Administration of Railway Transport of Ukraine (Ukrzaliznytsia) subsequently assumed responsibility for the EPC contract from CMCEC and it was charged with financing a scaled-down and rescoped version of the project. Construction began on May 22, 2018 and Ukrzaliznytsia announced on November 30, 2018 that the first trains had left from Kiev to Boryspil airport. Vladyslav Kaskiv, the former Head of Ukraine’s State Agency for Investment and National Projects, was closely involved in the Aerial Express Project. He put on an International wanted list in March 2016. He was detained in Panama in September 2016. A local court set his bail at $600,000. The Government of Panama refused to grant Kaskiv a political refugee status, and has was later extradited to Ukraine. Subsequently, Kaskiv was released on bail. As of May 2020, his case was pending before the High Anti-Corruption Court of Ukraine. Ukrzaliznytsia, a nationally owned company of Ukraine, took over the implementation and finished construction in a smaller scale. On November 30, 2018, Ukrzaliznytsia launched an express train to Boryspil airport with a floating schedule of 21-30 voyages per day.
justification: Project focuses on transportation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of passenger railway, train stations, and supporting systems for airport-city connection

title: China Eximbank provides $28.5 million preferential buyer's credit to faciliate the acquistion of dredgers (linked to #70581)
description: On April 19, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Uzbekistan signed a $28.5 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement to facilitate the acquisition of dredgers. The PBC carries the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate.  The loan proceeds were to be used to purchase 30 dredgers to clean the banks of Amudarya River and its channels. This project is Phase I of the Amudarya River clean-up. Phase II of the project is recorded in project #70581.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
China Eximbank provides $28.5 million preferential buyer's credit to faciliate the acquistion of dredgers (linked to #70581)

# Description
On April 19, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Uzbekistan signed a $28.5 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement to facilitate the acquisition of dredgers. The PBC carries the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate.  The loan proceeds were to be used to purchase 30 dredgers to clean the banks of Amudarya River and its channels. This project is Phase I of the Amudarya River clean-up. Phase II of the project is recorded in project #70581.
justification: Project focuses on water supply and sanitation through river clean-up, with no direct energy transition impact
evidence: Acquisition of dredgers for Amudarya River clean-up, water supply and sanitation sector

title: Chinese Government provides $500,000 grant for earthquake relief
description: On July 20, 2011, the Chinese Government pledged to provide the Government of Uzbekistan with a $500,000 grant for emergency relief after an earthquake.  On December 26, 2011, Chinese ambassador Zhang Wei and Uzbekistan’s Deputy Minister of Finance Jorkin Tulsonov signed an intergovernmental transfer certificate for the Uzbek government’s $500,000 foreign exchange humanitarian assistance project in Tashkent.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government provides $500,000 grant for earthquake relief

# Description
On July 20, 2011, the Chinese Government pledged to provide the Government of Uzbekistan with a $500,000 grant for emergency relief after an earthquake.  On December 26, 2011, Chinese ambassador Zhang Wei and Uzbekistan’s Deputy Minister of Finance Jorkin Tulsonov signed an intergovernmental transfer certificate for the Uzbek government’s $500,000 foreign exchange humanitarian assistance project in Tashkent.
justification: Project is humanitarian aid for earthquake relief with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: $500,000 grant for emergency relief, humanitarian assistance project
